Kawasaki-like Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (KMISC)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: Fever, oropharyngeal erythema, and periungal desquamation are classic symptoms of Kawasaki disease.  While pyuria is less common, sterile pyuria can occur in Kawasaki disease.}, {diagnosis: Scarlet fever

justification: Scarlet fever, caused by group A streptococcus, presents with fever, oropharyngeal erythema, and a characteristic sandpaper-like rash that can involve the hands and feet, leading to desquamation. Pyuria can be present in some cases.}, {diagnosis: Toxic shock syndrome

justification: Toxic shock syndrome can cause fever, oropharyngeal erythema, and a diffuse erythematous rash that can desquamate. Pyuria may be present due to associated urinary tract infection or as a systemic inflammatory response.}, {diagnosis: Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN)

justification: SJS/TEN are severe mucocutaneous reactions characterized by fever, oropharyngeal erythema, and widespread skin detachment, including periungal desquamation. Pyuria can occur due to secondary infection or systemic inflammation.}, {diagnosis: Leptospirosis

justification: Leptospirosis can present with fever, oropharyngeal erythema (often conjunctival suffusion), and rash. Pyuria is a common finding due to renal involvement.}, {diagnosis: Hand, foot, and mouth disease

justification: While not typically associated with pyuria, hand, foot, and mouth disease can cause fever, oropharyngeal erythema, and periungal desquamation as part of its characteristic vesicular rash.}, {diagnosis: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: DRESS syndrome can cause fever, oropharyngeal erythema, and a widespread rash that can desquamate. Pyuria may be present due to renal involvement.}, {diagnosis: Infectious mononucleosis

justification: While less common, infectious mononucleosis can cause fever, oropharyngeal erythema, and a rash. Pyuria might be present due to secondary bacterial infection or rarely, interstitial nephritis.}, {diagnosis: Measles

justification: Measles typically presents with fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash. However, oropharyngeal erythema (Koplik spots) and periungal desquamation can occur. Pyuria is not typical but can be seen with secondary bacterial infections.}, {diagnosis: Non-infectious causes
justification: Consider non-infectious causes such as autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus) or drug reactions that can cause fever, oropharyngeal erythema, rash, and pyuria.}
